explanations.A: Not quite! An equation is where two mathematical expressions are equal, so they always have an = sign.
explanations.B: y squared is a term, as it fits the definition of a term, which is: a single number (positive or negative), a single variable ( a letter ), several variables multiplied but never added or subtracted
explanations.C: Not quite! The y is a variable, but because the squared is also highlighted, there is an operation being performed on the variable making this something else.
explanations.D: Not quite! If the - 9 was also highlighted this would be an expression, as an operation has been performed and there is more than one term.

explanations.B: Not quite! If the + 4 was also highlighted this would be an expression, as an operation has been performed and there is more than one term.

explanations.D: p cubed is a term, as it fits the definition of a term, which is: a single number (positive or negative), a single variable ( a letter ), several variables multiplied but never added or subtracted

explanations.A: Not quite! An equation is where two mathematical expressions are equal, so they always have an = sign.
explanations.B: Not quite! A term refers to either a single number or variable, or ones multiplied together, but there are two terms here, separated by the subtraction sign. This means we call the group of things by another name.
explanations.C: Not quite! y is the variable, but numbers, symbols and operators have also been highlighted here, meaning it cannot just be a variable.
explanations.D: This is an expression, as there are variables, numbers and operators grouped together.

explanations.B: This is an expression, as there are variables, numbers and operators grouped together.
explanations.C: Not quite! An equation is where two mathematical expressions are equal, so they always have an = sign.
explanations.D: Not quite! A term refers to either a single number or variable, or ones multiplied together, but there are two terms here, separated by the addition sign. This means we call the group of things by another name.

explanations.A: Not quite! 6 is a factor of 6n², but 6 is not a factor of 9. Remember, a factor of a number is any number that you can divide by without leaving a remainder. Which number can you divide both 6n² and 9 by so that there is no remainder?
explanations.B: Not Quite! 9 is not a factor of 6n², but it is a factor of 9. Remember, a factor of a number is any number that you can divide by without leaving a remainder. Which number can you divide both 6n² and 9 by so that there is no remainder?
explanations.C: Not quite! n is a factor of 6n², but it is not a factor of 9. Remember, a factor of a number is any number that you can divide by without leaving a remainder. Which number can you divide both 6n² and 9 by so that there is no remainder left?
explanations.D: 6n² ÷ 3 = 2n² and 9 ÷ 3 = 3. As there is no remainder in either of these calculations 3 is a common factor of both 6n² and 9, so it is a factor of the whole expression.

explanations.A: Not Quite! k is a factor of 15k³, but not a factor of 10. Remember, a factor of a number is any number that you can divide by without leaving a remainder. Which number can you divide both 15k³ and 10 by so that there is no remainder?
explanations.B: 15k³ ÷ 5 = 3k³ and 10 ÷ 5 = 2. As there is no remainder in either of these calculations 5 is a common factor of both 15k³ and10, so it is a common factor of the whole expression.
explanations.C: Not quite! 15 is a factor of 15k³ but not a factor of 10. Remember, a factor of a number is any number that you can divide by without leaving a remainder. Which number can you divide both 15k³ and 10 by so that there is no remainder?
explanations.D: Not quite! 10 is a factor of 10, but it is not a factor of 15k³. Remember, a factor of a number is any number that you can divide by without leaving a remainder. Which number can you divide both 15k³ and 10 by so that there is no remainder?

explanations.A: Not quite! An equation is where two mathematical expressions are equal, so they always have an = sign.
explanations.B: Not quite! A term refers to either a single number or variable, or ones multiplied together, for example 7m. We are only being asked about the m here.
explanations.C: A variable is a letter or symbol which represents a quantity that can change. In the expression 5 - 7m, m is the variable.
explanations.D: Not quite! 5 - 7m is an expression, as there are terms, variables and operators. We are only being asked about the m here.

explanations.A: A variable is a letter or symbol which represents a quantity that can change. In the expression 9 - 3t, t is the variable.
explanations.B: Not quite! 9 - 3t is an expression, as there are terms, variables and operators. We are only being asked about the t here.
explanations.C: Not quite! An equation is where two mathematical expressions are equal, so they always have an = sign.
explanations.D: A term refers to either a single number or variable, or ones multiplied together, for example 3t. We are only being asked about the t here.

explanations.A: Not quite! 6 is a factor of 6p², but 6 is not a factor of 11p. Remember, 6p² = 6 ✕ p ✕ p and 11p = 11 ✕ p. What number or letter is a common factor to both of these terms?
explanations.B: Not quite! 11 is a factor of 11p, but 11 is not a factor of 6p². Remember, 6p² = 6 ✕ p ✕ p and 11p = 11 ✕ p. What number or letter is a common factor to both of these terms?
explanations.C: Not quite! p² is a factor of 6p², but p² is not a factor of 11p. Remember, 6p² = 6 ✕ p ✕ p and 11p = 11 ✕ p. What number or letter is a common factor to both of these terms?
explanations.D: 6p² = 6 ✕ p ✕ p and 11p = 11 ✕ p. Both these terms have p as a factor therefore p is a common factor of both 6p² and 11p, so it is a factor of the whole expression.

explanations.A: Not quite! m² is a factor of 2m², but m² is not a factor of 9m. Remember, 2m² = 2 ✕ m ✕ m and 9m = 9 ✕ m. What number or letter is a common factor to both of these terms?
explanations.B: 2m² = 2 ✕ m ✕ m and 9m = 9 ✕ m. Both these terms have m as a factor therefore m is a common factor of both 2m² and 9m, so it is a factor of the whole expression.
explanations.C: Not quite! 2 is a factor of 2m², but 2 is not a factor of 9m. Remember, 2m² = 2 ✕ m ✕ m and 9m = 9 ✕ m. What number or letter is a common factor to both of these terms?
explanations.D: Not quite! 9 is a factor of 9m, but 9 is not a factor of 2m². Remember, 2m² = 2 ✕ m ✕ m and 9m = 9 ✕ m. What number or letter is a common factor to both of these terms?
